simulation_equations: M_dot = 4 * pi * R_star^2 * rho_0 * V_inf * f_geom
I_lambda(i, v_rot, beta) = integral over visible hemisphere of emission_function(r, theta, phi, i, v_rot, beta)
v_proj(r, theta, phi, i) = v(r) * sin(theta) * cos(phi) * sin(i) + v_rot * sin(theta) * sin(phi) * sin(i)
beta_obs = fit_parameter from synthetic line profiles

constants_required.name: R_star
constants_required.description: Stellar radius for O6.5 III star

constants_required.name: M_star
constants_required.description: Stellar mass for O6.5 III star

constants_required.name: V_inf_base
constants_required.description: Wind terminal velocity for non-rotating case

constants_required.name: beta_intrinsic
constants_required.description: Intrinsic wind velocity law exponent for slow rotators

constants_required.name: alpha_gravity_darkening
constants_required.description: Gravity darkening parameter for wind density distribution

variables_to_vary.name: beta_model
variables_to_vary.description: Input wind velocity law exponent for model grid

procedure_steps: Step 1: Initialize constants (R_star, M_star, L_star, V_inf_base, M_dot_base, Z, alpha_gravity_darkening) and create parameter grids for v_rot (0-400 km/s), inclination (0-90°), and beta_model (0.8-2.5)

Step 2: For each combination of (v_rot, inclination, beta_model): (a) Compute the 3D wind velocity field v(r, theta) using the beta law with rotation effects; (b) Compute the wind density distribution rho(r, theta) with gravity darkening g(theta) = 1 + alpha * cos(theta)^2 to account for polar enhancement in fast rotators

Step 3: Generate synthetic line profiles by integrating emission over the visible stellar hemisphere: (a) Set up spherical grid (r, theta, phi) from R_star to 5*R_star; (b) For each grid point, compute projected velocity v_proj including both wind velocity and rotational velocity; (c) Compute emission coefficient proportional to rho(r, theta)^2 for optically thin lines; (d) Project onto velocity space accounting for inclination angle i; (e) Convolve with instrumental profile

Step 4: Fit the synthetic line profiles to extract observed beta_obs: (a) Use least-squares fitting to match profile shape with beta law; (b) Record beta_obs for each (v_rot, inclination) combination; (c) Compare beta_obs to input beta_model to quantify viewing angle effects

Step 5: Compute wind momentum D_mom = M_dot * V_inf * R_star^0.5 for each model, adjusting M_dot for rotation effects using M_dot(v_rot) = M_dot_base * (1 + 0.3 * (v_rot/v_crit)^2) to account for enhanced equatorial mass loss

Step 6: Test the hypothesis by analyzing results: (a) For fast rotators (v_rot > 200 km/s) at low inclination (i < 30°), verify that beta_obs > 1.5; (b) For slow rotators or high inclination, verify that beta_obs ≈ 0.8-1.0; (c) Plot log(D_mom) vs log(L_star/L_sun) for all models and verify they follow the same WLR with slope ≈ 1.8-2.0 regardless of rotation/inclination

Step 7: Generate visualizations: (a) 2D heatmap of beta_obs vs (v_rot, inclination); (b) Line profile comparison for fast rotator at i=10° vs i=70°; (c) Wind momentum-luminosity diagram showing all models collapse onto single relation; (d) Contour plot showing regions where beta_obs > 1.5 in (v_rot, inclination) space

Step 8: Quantify systematic effects: (a) Calculate mean beta_obs for fast rotators (v_rot > 200 km/s) at i < 30° and compare to slow rotators; (b) Compute scatter in WLR for different rotation/inclination combinations; (c) Determine critical rotation velocity and inclination angle where beta_obs transitions from normal to elevated values
expected_outcomes: The simulation should reveal: (1) A strong dependence of observed beta (beta_obs) on the combination of rotation velocity and inclination angle, with fast rotators (v_rot > 200 km/s) viewed at low inclination (i < 30°) showing systematically elevated beta_obs > 1.5, while slow rotators or high-inclination systems show beta_obs ≈ 0.8-1.0. (2) Synthetic line profiles for fast rotators at low inclination should exhibit enhanced emission at intermediate velocities due to the superposition of wind regions with different velocities and densities, mimicking a steeper velocity law. (3) Despite the variation in observed beta, all models should follow the same wind momentum-luminosity relationship when plotted as log(D_mom) vs log(L_star), with a tight correlation (scatter < 0.3 dex) and slope consistent with radiatively driven wind theory (≈1.8-2.0). (4) A clear transition region in (v_rot, inclination) parameter space where beta_obs increases from normal to elevated values, demonstrating that the high beta observed in GHV-62024 is indeed an artifact of viewing geometry rather than a fundamental change in wind physics. (5) The 2D heatmap should show a diagonal pattern where the combination of high rotation and low inclination produces the highest beta_obs values, validating the paper's interpretation that GHV-62024's unusual properties result from being a fast rotator seen nearly pole-on.
